The modern calendar was devised by an emperor of [[Shou Lung]] in ancient times, in order to fix the dates of various annual festivals and holidays. In this, it was very successful and was widely adopted by all the civilized cultures of Kara-Tur by the mid–14th century [[DR]].

Months.Tsou (30 days): [[New Year's Festival]]; holy day of the [[Celestial Emperor|God of Heaven]]; [[Feast of Lanterns]]; holy day of the God of Spring; holy day of the [[Hsing Yong|God of Wealth]]; [[Fertility Festival]]; holy day of the God of Happiness; holy day of the God of Learning.
Months.Ju (30 days): Holy day of the God of North; holy day of the [[Kwan Ying|Goddess of Mercy]].
Months.Yu (30 days): Holy day of the God of Central Mound; holy day of the Queen of Heaven; [[Cherry Blossom Festival]];
Months.Kao (30 days): Birthday of [[Saizu]], the great teacher who founded the [[Path of Enlightenment]] in [[Wa]]; holy day of the God of Medicine; holy day of the God of South. The first day of a period called Shiang began in this month.
Months.Kao II (29 days): Holy day of the [[Lei Kung|Thunder God]]; [[Dragon Boat Festival]]; holy day of the [[Chan Cheng|God of War]].
Months.Chu (30 days): ;Hsiang (29 days): Holy day of the God of Fire; [[Purification Festival]].
Months.Chuang (30 days): [[Moon Feast Festival]]; holy day of the [[Nung Chiang|God of Land and Grain]]; holy day of the [[Shu Chia|God of Furnace]]; [[Great Sage's Birthday]].
Months.Hsuan (30 days): Holy day of the Wine God; [[Yang Feast]]; holy day of the Polar Gods; holy day of the [[Hsing Yong|God of Wealth]].
Months.Yang (29 days): Holy day of the God of Disease.
Months.Ku (30 days):
;Tu (29 days): [[King's Festival]].

Other months were also recorded:
Months.Lotan: The first day of a period called Matu began in this month.
Months.Maki: A cold winter month observed in [[Tabot]].<ref>

document_data.Events: The calendar included many special feasts, festivals, and holidays celebrated by the many cultures of Kara-Tur. Feasts were causes to gather in numbers and enjoy a grand banquet, or at least an affordable one. Festivals were celebrations that could run for several days, and even weeks. Holy days were dedicated to one or more gods; whether or not they were observed in a community depended on its culture and dominant faith. Where they were observed, they were simple affairs, and were typically a reason for a feast.
document_data.Years: The years sometimes had names: {{YearlinkConvert|2607|SY}} was known as the Year of the Great Sky Serpent, and {{YearlinkConvert|581|SY}} was known as the year of the Ding Hai.
